graph

Class DirectedGraph<N,L>

  • java.lang.Object
    • graph.DirectedGraph<N,L>

  • public class DirectedGraph<N,L>
extends java.lang.Object
    A DirectedGraph models relationships between nodes. The objects in the graph are referred to as nodes and the relationships between those nodes are called edges. Each edge connects two nodes.

    The edges are directed (one-way). So e => (n1, n2) means that there is a path from node n1 to n2. Node n1 is referred to as the source node, and n2 is referred to as the target node.

    There can be any number of edges (zero, one, or more) between a pair of nodes.

    Each edge also has a label.

    Graph nodes and Edge labels are generic types that you must specify. The type of node is N, and the type of Edge label is L.

    DirectedGraph is technically a type of graph called a "directed labeled multi-graph", which you can read more about at: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multigraph
    Author:
    Janelle Van Hofwegen

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      DirectedGraph()
      Constructs an empty DirectedGraph with no nodes, no edges
      DirectedGraph(java.util.List<N> nodes)
      Constructs a DirectedGraph containing the nodes within list nodes
      DirectedGraph(java.util.List<N> nodes, java.util.List<graph.Edge<N,L>> edges)
      Constructs a DirectedGraph containing the nodes within list nodes, and all the Edges within list edges.

      • edgesOf

        public java.util.List<graph.Edge<N,L>> edgesOf(N node)
        Returns a List of all edges whose source is node. Therefore every Edge e in the List follows the form e = (node, some other node)
        Parameters:
        node - - the source node for which a set of edges is being returned
        Returns:
        a Set of all edges whose source is node. Returned set is empty if the node has no edges.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if node == null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if node node is not contained within the graph
        Requires:
        • node != null
        • that node is contained within the method

      • leastPaths

        public java.util.List<graph.Edge<N,L>> leastPaths(N a,
                                         N b)
        Finds and returns the shortest path (in terms of # of nodes visited) to get from node a to node b. Returns this path as an ordered list of edges that can be followed to get from a to b.
        The first edge of the list is the starting edge. It points from a to the second node in the path. The last edge of the list is the ending edge. It points from the second to last node in the path to node b.
        If node a and node b are not connected by any path, returns null.
        Parameters:
        a - - the source node for which a set of edges is being returned
        Returns:
        a List of edges representing the shortest (in terms of nodes visited)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if a == null or b == null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if a and/or b is not in the graph
        Requires:
        • a != null, b != null
        • that a and b are both contained within the graph
